title: Analysis of Outer Space Objects
text:
1 - Introduction
This project investigates and analyzes the trends and contributions of the global entities in launching outer space objects. By aiming to understand how the number of objects launched have changed over time, we can try to identify the key contributors.


2 - Workspace Setup

# Plot Theme
ggplot2::theme_set(ggplot2::theme_minimal(base_size = 14))

# Set Width of Code Output
options(width = 65)

# Set Figure Parameters for knitr
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  fig.width = 7,        # 7" width
  fig.asp = 0.618,      # the golden ratio
  fig.retina = 3,       # dpi multiplier for displaying HTML output on retina
  fig.align = "center", # center align figures
  dpi = 300             # higher dpi, sharper image
)

# Loading Packages
pacman::p_load("dplyr", "gsubfn", "here", "knitr", "tidyr", "stringr", "tidyverse")
pacman::p_load("rworldmap", "rworldxtra", "maps", "ggplot2", "patchwork", "gtable", "gt")

# Loading Necessary Dataset
space_data <- read.csv(here("data/outer_space_objects.csv"))
gdp_data <- read.csv(here("data/gdp_data_top_5.csv"))



3 - Dataset

glimpse(space_data)

Rows: 1,175
Columns: 4
$ Entity      <chr> "APSCO", "Algeria", "Algeria", "Algeria", "â€¦
$ Code        <chr> "", "DZA", "DZA", "DZA", "DZA", "AGO", "AGOâ€¦
$ Year        <int> 2023, 2002, 2010, 2016, 2017, 2017, 2022, 1â€¦
$ num_objects <int> 1, 1, 1, 3, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1â€¦

glimpse(gdp_data)

Rows: 5
Columns: 10
$ Country.Name   <chr> "China", "Germany", "India", "Japan", "Uâ€¦
$ Country.Code   <chr> "CHN", "DEU", "IND", "JPN", "USA"
$ Indicator.Name <chr> "GDP (current US$)", "GDP (current US$)"â€¦
$ Indicator.Code <chr> "NY.GDP.MKTP.CD", "NY.GDP.MKTP.CD", "NY.â€¦
$ X2018          <chr> "13,900,000,000,000", "3,970,000,000,000â€¦
$ X2019          <chr> "14,300,000,000,000", "3,890,000,000,000â€¦
$ X2020          <chr> "14,700,000,000,000", "3,890,000,000,000â€¦
$ X2021          <chr> "17,800,000,000,000", "4,280,000,000,000â€¦
$ X2022          <chr> "18,000,000,000,000", "4,080,000,000,000â€¦
$ X2023          <chr> "17,900,000,000,000", "4,400,000,000,000â€¦


I have chosen this Outer Space Objects dataset. This dataset contains detailed information about the various entities launching outer space objects over the course of time. Each entry or record contains the entityâ€™s name, the ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 code for some specific entities, the year when this observation was captured, and the number of objects launched.
I am particularly interested in the growing field of space exploration and monitoring, understanding the trends in object launch events, and identifying these major contributors can provide valuable insights in the progress and focus areas. This analysis could potentially highlight the advancements in space technologies and the collaborative efforts of different entities worldwide.
This dataset also allows me to explore the dynamics of contributions from various countries. By analyzing these contributions over time, we can gain a deeper understanding of the shifts in focus and resource allocation in the domain of deep space monitoring. Such insights could inform strategics for future investments and collaborations in space exploration, monitoring, and soon enough, militarization.

space_data_summary <- paste(
  nrow(space_data), min(space_data$Year), max(space_data$Year)
)

print(space_data_summary)

[1] "1175 1957 2023"

gdp_data_summary <- paste(
  nrow(gdp_data)
)

print(gdp_data_summary)

[1] "5"


The dataset outer_space_objects.csv contains 1175 entries with information on outer space objects recorded by different entities. The columns in it are : â€˜Entityâ€™, â€˜Codeâ€™, â€˜Yearâ€™, and â€˜num_objectsâ€™. The dataset spans from 1957, to the most recent 2023. Since this dataset is not only very comprehensive, but also primarily quantitative, it allows for a detailed analysis of trends and contributions over time.
The dataset gdp_data_top_5.csv contains 5 entries with information on GDPs of the BIG 5. The columns in it are : â€˜Country.Nameâ€™, â€˜Country.Codeâ€™, â€˜Indicator.Nameâ€™, â€˜Indicator.Codeâ€™, â€˜X2018â€™, â€˜X2019â€™, â€˜X2020â€™, â€˜X2021â€™, â€˜X2022â€™, and â€˜X2023â€™.


4 - Questions
After taking into consideration, feedback from my peers, questions have been altered.

What are the trends in the number of outer space objects launched over the years ?
Which entities have contributed the most to the number of outer space objects launched ? Considering the TOP 5 Economies in the world have changed over the years, how have their space launch programs reacted to the changes in their respective economies ?

Q3 is NOT a necessary question, but Iâ€™m just curious, so Iâ€™m going to attempt it.

If we have to predict the future, how will the the outer space object launch trend line look like ?



5 - Analysis Plan
Based on my analysis, analysis plan has been altered.

Trends Over the Years :

Variables Involved - Year, total_objects.
Plan :

Aggregate the space data by year.
Create a smooth line plot to show the trend of total objects launched over the years.
Create a line plot to show the accurate trend of total objects launched over the years, highlighting any discrepancies in trends.
Highlight recent years for focus.


BIG 5 :

Overall Space Launch Trends :

Variables Involved - Year, total_objects, Entity.
Plan -

Aggregate the space data for the TOP 5 economies based on their GDP.
Create a smooth line plot to visualize the number of objects launched by the BIG 5 since the 1950s.
Use GDP data to provide context and insights into the space launch capabilities.


Geo - Distribution of Recent Launch Trends :

Variables Involved - world_map, Latitude, Longitude, total_objects, Entity
Plan -

Use a world map to plot the geographic distribution of recent space launches.
Overlay the launch data onto the geographic centers (centroids) of the BIG 5 respectively.
Use size points to represent the total number of objects launched.



Outer Space Launch Prediction :

Variables Involved - yearly_data, forecast_model
Plan -

Implement a forecast model to predict future launches.
Allow user to choose the prediction model from ARIMA, ETS, and TBATS, as well as the number of years to forecast (LIMIT 27).
Display the forecast results with confidence intervals on a line plot.





6 - Modus Operandi
I have something in mind for this, I just hope itâ€™s possible.ðŸ˜£
I had something in mind for this, I just hoped itâ€™s possible. IT IS AND I DID IT. ðŸ˜Ž

title: Analysis of Outer Space Objects
text:
This project aims to analyze the trends and predict future activities of countries involved in launching outer space objects since 1957 till 2023. For this, I am utilizing the dataset, outer_space_objects.csv, sourced from TidyTuesday, originally sourced from United Nations Office of Outer Space Affairs. Another dataset, gdp_data_top_5.csv, compiled from information from World Bank Database, is also being utilized here.
My analysis is divided into several KEY sections :

Trends Over The Years :

Aggregating and visualizing the total number of objects launched globally from 1957 to 2023.
Using ggplot2 to create smooth and accurate time-series plots to illustrate the overall trends, and highlighting specific periods of space activity, to provide strategic insights.

The BIG 5 :

Identifying and focusing on the top five countries with the highest GDPs - United States, China, Germany, Japan, and India. By filtering the dataset, analyzing the launch trends of these countries, while also providing insights into the relationship between their GDPs and the number of objects launched.
Creating smooth line plots visualizing the trend in the number of objects launched by them since the 1950s.
Providing a panoramic perspective by creating a world map plot showcasing the geographic distribution of the most recent launches, along with size points representing the total number of objects launched by them.

Outer Space Object Launch Prediction :

In order to forecast the number of outer space objects that will be launched in the future, develop an interactive Shiny application.
Users can choose between different forecasting models, which are ARIMA, ETS, and TBATS.
The application will generate dynamic visualizations and summaries, allowing users to explore various scenarios and gain insights into future trends.




Workspace Setup
# Plot Theme
ggplot2::theme_set(ggplot2::theme_minimal(base_size = 14))

# Set Width of Code Output
options(width = 65)

# Set Figure Parameters for knitr
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  fig.width = 7,        # 7" Width
  fig.asp = 0.618,      # The Golden Ratio
  fig.retina = 3,       # DPI Multiplier for Displaying HTML Output on Retina
  fig.align = "center", # Center Align Figures
  dpi = 300             # Higher DPI, Sharper Image
)

# Loading Packages
pacman::p_load("dplyr", "ggplot2", "grid", "gridExtra", "gsubfn", "here", "knitr", "maps", "stringr", "tidyr", "tidyverse")
pacman::p_load("gganimate", "forecast", "shiny")

space_data <- read.csv(here("data/outer_space_objects.csv"))
gdp_data <- read.csv(here("data/gdp_data_top_5.csv"))

title: Analysis of Outer Space Objects
text:
2A - Overall Trends


BIG 5 Comparison Plot
# Line Plot of Number of Objects Launched by the BIG 5 Countries
ggplot(launch_trends, aes(x = Year, y = total_objects, color = Entity)) +
  geom_smooth(se = FALSE, size = 1) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      "United States" = "cyan",
      "China" = "red",
      "Germany" = "green",
      "Japan" = "yellow",
      "India" = "orange"
    ),
    name = "Country"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Outer Space Object Launches by the BIG 5 by Year (1958 - 2023)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Total Objects Launched",
    caption = "Space Data Collected from : United Nations Office of Outer Space Affairs\nObjects include, but are not limited to: Landers, Probes, Satellites, etc.\nGDP Data Collected from : World Bank Database."
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 12.5, hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 7.5, hjust = 0.5),
    legend.position = "top",
    legend.justification = c("center", "top"),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = alpha('white', 0.5)),
    plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5)
  )

title: Analysis of Outer Space Objects
text:
2B - Broader Perspective


BIG 5 World Map
# Loading World Map Data
world_map <- map_data("world")

# Defining Country Colors
country_colors <- c(
  "United States" = "cyan",
  "China" = "red",
  "Germany" = "green",
  "Japan" = "yellow",
  "India" = "orange"
)

# Correcting Country Names in the World Map Data to match the Specified Country Names
world_map <- world_map %>%
  mutate(region = case_when(
    region == "USA" ~ "United States",
    region == "China" ~ "China",
    region == "Germany" ~ "Germany",
    region == "Japan" ~ "Japan",
    region == "India" ~ "India",
    TRUE ~ region
  ))

# Adding Color based on Country
world_map <- world_map %>%
  mutate(fill = case_when(
    region == "United States" ~ "cyan",
    region == "China" ~ "red",
    region == "Germany" ~ "green",
    region == "Japan" ~ "yellow",
    region == "India" ~ "orange",
    TRUE ~ "lightgray"
  ))

# Plotting Map
ggplot() +
  geom_polygon(data = world_map, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill = fill), color = "white") +
  geom_point(data = Space_GDP_Data_2, aes(x = lon, y = lat, size = total_objects), alpha = 0.1) +
  scale_size(range = c(3, 15)) +
  scale_fill_identity() +
  labs(
    title = "Geo - Distribution of Launches by the BIG 5 by Year (2018 - 2023)",
    subtitle = "Size of the Points Represents Total Objects Launched",
    x = "Longitude",
    y = "Latitude",
    size = "Total Objects",
    caption = "Space Data Collected from : United Nations Office of Outer Space Affairs\nObjects include, but are not limited to : Landers, Probes, Satellites, etc.\nGDP Data Collected from : World Bank Database."
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 12.5, hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 7.5, hjust = 0.5),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "right",
    legend.title = element_text(size = 7.5),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 7),
    plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5)
  )

title: About
text:
This project was developed by Manas P Panse For INFO 526 - Data Analysis and Visualization at the University of Arizona, taught by Dr.Â Greg Chism. The team is comprised of the following team members.

Manas P Panse : Currently pursuing MS - DS @ iSchool, University of Arizona.

title: Analysis of Outer Space Objects
text:
1 - Introduction


This project explores the intersection of outer space launch activities AND economic power. This project involves utilizing two datasets, one dataset contains detailed information about the various entities launching outer space objects over the course of time. Each entry or record contains the entityâ€™s name, the ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 code for some specific entities, the year when this observation was captured, and the number of objects launched. The other dataset focuses on the BIG 5, i.e China, Germany, India, Japan, and the United States, where each record contains the country names, their ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 code, Indicator Name, the Indicator Code, and their GDPâ€™s since 2018 until 2023.
The motivation behind choosing these datasets stems from the following reasons :

Technological Innovation.
Alignment with Economic Power.
Geopolitical Implications.
